channel.title: Posts on koolaidxk1d
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on koolaidxk1d

item.title: OverTheWire: Natas
item.description: Back for more password hunting! This time we are doing a more web-oriented wargame. Similarly to leviathan, no hints are given on the webpage. This game provides no SSH access; everything is done in the browser. I’m lacking in web-dev knowledge to say the least, so this will be quite challenging. Level 0 The password is right in your face the moment you look at the html. Level 1 Same story as level 0, however the workaround is just using the hotkey to open the inspector.

item.title: Cool Links
item.description: https://based.cooking/ - simple recipe website without the web bloat https://slipfox.xyz - free uploads, link shortening, and way more https://teachyourselfcs.com/ - roadmap for self-taught CS education https://book.hacktricks.xyz/ - wiki with some useful info https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/index.html - OWASP Cheat Sheets https://evoxt.com/ - cheap VPS, good customer support https://new.reddit.com/r/hacking/wiki/index/ - good resources listed here https://gchq.github.io/CyberChef/ - Extremely useful all-in-one hacking web tool https://dogbolt.org - Online decompiler http://redtiger.labs.overthewire.org/ - SQL Injection Lab (not listed on OTW) (possibly more unindexed labs can be found thru google)

item.title: About Me
item.description: Y2K zoomer interested in offensive security. No professional experience … yet. The purpose of my blog is to learn in public. Hopefully by writing these posts I can not only help myself but possibly help others who stumble upon them. Thanks This blog is written with Obsidian, compiled with Hugo, and hosted with Github pages. The Hugo theme in use is Diary. Music backgrounds taken from ericaofanderson on tumblr.

item.title: OverTheWire: Leviathan
item.description: OverTheWire’s Leviathan wargame is all about reverse engineering of x86 binaries. The description of the game states that it only requires knowledge of linux command line utilities, and little to no programming experience. Each level goes as such: You ssh into the server as the user whose password you obtained from the previous level. Through whatever means necessary, you get the password to the next level. There are no hints given for any of the levels, so it is completely up to us to figure out what we are looking for.
